user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32                              final_status;
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    final_status = OS_SUCCESS;
    impl         = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    status = pthread_cond_destroy(&impl->cv);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        final_status = OS_ERROR;
    }

    status = pthread_mutex_destroy(&impl->mut);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        final_status = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return final_status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarDelete_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No unreachable code fragments were identified in the provided function. Rationale: 
- There are no statements placed after an unconditional return; the single return at the end is reachable. 
- The two if-statements test the runtime return value of pthread_cond_destroy and pthread_mutex_destroy (status != 0); these depend on the OS/thread library at runtime and thus their bodies are potentially reachable. 
- The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro expands to an index lookup using OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok)), where OS_ObjectIndexFromToken reads token->obj_idx; this depends on the runtime token value (passed as *token), so the table access is not a compile-time constant that would make code unreachable. 
- There are no constant boolean expressions, unconditional goto/branching that would make subsequent code unreachable, and no dead labels or unused code blocks in the shown function. 
Given the provided definitions and the absence of any always-true/always-false compile-time conditions or unreachable control-flow constructs in the excerpt, there is no code here that needs investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.
